Prehistory—hundreds of Indian tribes throughout California 1542 Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo leads the first expedition of Europeans to California
1769 Spanish arrive and begin building missions, presidios, and towns 1822 Mexican (and Californian) independence from Spain
Mexico cedes California to U.S. following U.S.–Mexican War Gold discovered 1850 Statehood 1869 Transcontinental railroad completed
New constitution intended to weaken the power of the railroad political machine
Progressive reformers elect Governor Hiram Johnson and a majority in the state legislature; electoral reforms follow Women win the right to vote
California elects its only Democratic governor between 1894 and
Japanese Americans removed from their communities and interned during World War II 1955 Disneyland opens in Anaheim 1963 California is #1 state in population
Intel produces its first microprocessor; Silicon Valley is born
Political Reform Act requires disclosure of sources of campaign funds 1978 Proposition 13 reforms property tax
Voters reject Chief Justice Rose Bird and two associate justices of the California Supreme Court 1990 Voters approve term limits for state legislators
California’s Silicon Valley surpasses metropolitan New York City as the nation’s top exporting region
Cruz Bustamante elected lieutenant governor—the first Latino elected to statewide office since 1871
Non-Hispanic whites become the minority as other groups reach 50.1 percent of the population
Governor Gray Davis recalled; Arnold Schwarzenegger elected
